byline.contributor: Mike Isaac reported from New York, Nick Wingfield from Seattle and Noam Scheiber from Washington.
byline.original: By MIKE ISAAC, NICK WINGFIELD and NOAM SCHEIBER

abstract: Seattle City Council plans to vote on law that proposes to give drivers like those who work for Uber and Lyft right to collectively bargain with companies about pay and working conditions; early indications suggest council will vote in favor of legislation, which will make App-Based Drivers Assn first organization of on-demand contract workers in country to be given right to unionize.
lead_paragraph: The Seattle City Council plans to vote on a proposed law to give freelance, on-demand drivers the right to collectively negotiate on pay and working conditions.

headline.main: Seattle Considers Measure to Let Uber and Lyft Drivers Unionize
headline.print_headline: Seattle Considers Letting Uber and Lyft Drivers Unionize

snippet: The Seattle City Council plans to vote on a proposed law to give freelance, on-demand drivers the right to collectively negotiate on pay and working conditions.
